trial_identification.studytitle: Reduction Of Chronic Post-surgical Pain with Ketamine A Pilot Study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A pilot study for a multicentre double-blind placebo controlled randomized Phase 4 study of the effect of ketamine on the development of chronic post-surgical pain in patients undergoing elective abdominal or non-cardiac thoracic surgery under general anaesthesia.

interventions.interventions: The effect of intravenous ketamine given prior to and for up to 24 hours following surgical incision on the prevalence and severity of chronic post-surgical pain at 4-6 months postoperatively. Ketamine dosage is 0. 5mg/kg bolus, followed by 0.25 mg/kg/hr intra-operatively. then 0.1 mg/kg/hr continued for 24 hour

primaryOutcome.outcome: The incidence of chronic post-surgical wound-related pain reported by the patient using a structured questionnaire incorporating the modified brief pain inventory (mBPI).

secondaryOutcome.outcome: The mean severity of chronic post-surgical wound-related pain measured using a Visual Analog Scale (0-100).
Quality of life estimates using the WHODAS and Kessler K-10 Depression scale, and their relationship to pain prevalence and severity
The severity of acute postoperative pain measured using a Visual Analog Scale (0-100).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: In the first 24, 48 and 72 hours postoperative

secondaryOutcome.outcome: The relationship of the severity of acute postoperative pain to chronic post surgical pain prevalence and severity using a Visual Analog Scale (0-100).

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patients undergoing elective abdominal or non-cardiac thoracic surgery under general anaesthesia involving a skin incision at least 8 cm in length and a hospital stay of at least one night postoperatively.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Patients unable to provide informed consent Patients with poor English language comprehension Patients who are pregnant Body mass index (BMI) over 40 kg/m2 or weight over 130kg ASA grade 4 or 5. Uncontrolled hypertension (SBP over 180 mmHg) or heart failure Intracranial surgery History of haemorrhagic stroke Previous adverse reaction to ketamine Patients with a documented chronic pain syndrome identified using the mBPI Patients with epilepsy or history of convulsions Patients with a history of psychiatric problems or drug abuse or illegal activities

trial_design.statisticalmethods: 80 patients. This study is a pilot study and is not powered to demonstrate a statistically significant difference in the primary endpoint

ethicsAndSummary.summary: There is a well established physiological basis for the proposition that a potent NMDA receptor antagonist such as the widely available drug ketamine given peri-operatively may reduce the development of chronic postsurgical pain in patients undergoing major surgery, and this proposition is supported by available data pooled from small placebo controlled published studies, and a large study on N2O. The potential benefits of this in reducing the burden of chronic pain in the community are substantial. A large multicentre randomized trial is needed in patients undergoing major surgery to determine whether chronic post-surgical pain is reduced using intravenous ketamine given peri-operatively.
